The "Vitamin A" in plant foods is a precursor. The body has to convert it into the active form of Vitamin A. From what I've read, the "...bioavailability and vitamin A equivalency of β-carotene are highly variable and can be affected by food- and diet-related factors, including the food matrix, food-processing techniques, size of the dose of β-carotene, and the amounts of dietary fat, fiber, vitamin A, and other carotenoids in the diet as well as by characteristics of the target population, such as vitamin A status, nutrient deficiencies, gut integrity, and genetic polymorphisms associated with β-carotene metabolism." (The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, Volume 96, Issue 5, November 2012, Pages 1193S–1203S.)

The Vitamin A in animal foods, by contrast, is the active form and more bioavailable. For those who eat animal foods that contain Vitamin A, there shouldn't be any issues. However, if one eats only plant foods, it's something to look into further and discuss with a doctor or nutritionist.

In discussing the family of B Vitamins, it's stated in the film that humans can't make B Vitamins. My understanding is that we actually can make some B Vitamins and Vitamin K in the gut, provided we're giving our microbiome the proper raw materials.

Also, regarding B Vitamins, there was no distinction between Folate (natural) and Folic Acid (synthetic), either. Some people have problems metabolizing Folic Acid and this can result in high levels of Homocysteine.

These are a few additional reasons to avoid junk food, as it's processed foods that are fortified -- often with the lowest quality nutrients and possibly in forms that aren't the most desirable.

My quibbles aside, I thought it was a good film and a great starting point.

Wow! What an amazing documentary. I wish I could watch it here in Germany as well!
But I don't quite agree with you though when you say that one carrot a day can supply you with the efficient amount of vitamin A that you need. Because carrots actually contain beta-carotene, which has to be transformed into vitamin A inside the body. And studies have shown that up to 40% of all Europeans for example lack the right genes to convert beta-carotene into vitamin A sufficiently. Those people could eat five carrots and still get a vitamin A deficiency. And I've also read in an article of the Cambridge University Press that beta-carotene can be best absorbed and converted into vitamin A if you eat it together with fat, because beta-carotene can be best ingested when it is dissolved in oil. That means that you'd have to eat your carrot together with fat or fry it in oil before eating it.

I’ve been a lifelong skeptic about taking vitamins, reasoning that I naturally gravitate toward a healthy, varied moderate and largely home-cooked diet.

But no more skepticism. In early April 2020, here in NYC - the hotspot for Coronavirus in the US - I discovered I had an acute Vitamin D deficiency (4.7 ng/ml vs. a reference range of 30-50). After 2-1/2 weeks of weekly megadoses of oral D3, in the wee hours of the night, I was hit with a profound sense of well-being, restored energy and a lifting of pain. My follow-up labs explained why: my level had already increased exactly 10-fold to 47 ng/ml.

Additionally, there is some preliminary research that suggests that a vitamin D deficiency can make Covid-19 much worse if you become infected.

The problem with multi-vitamin/mineral supplements are two-fold.
1. Vitamins based on organic compounds are simply superior and most useful to our bodies. Synthetics are not, and some, like Vit C Ascorbic Acid are not actually what they claim to be. Little known fact, Vit C as Ascorbic Acid does not, and can not cure scurvy. A potatoe or citrus lemon/lime with actual Vit. C will.
2. Most supplements use inorganic minerals such as calcium carbonate or mag. oxide, which are non-chelated. The body usually can only get 1-2% bioavailability. Organic minerals are chelated with a carbon atom, and they and many chelated-inorganic minerals have much higher availability.

I'm not a salad guy, however leafy greens and cruciferous vegetables are much better for multiple reasons compared to the convenient yet minimally useful supplements one normally finds in the shop.

Getting Vitamins via through diet or natural means (i.e. Vitamin D made via sunlight) is the best way to get all your vitamins.  BUT if you have no means of getting it through nutrition or natural means, then taking dietary supplements is your best choice.  Just make sure you use one that is of a reputable source (a brand you are familiar with or you see common in your area).

I'm a pharmacist and a formulation scientist, my advice is to get vitamins from eating veg and fruits and other foods and to be exposed enough to the sun unless you are in a very high demand. There are numerous advantages to that over pilling yourself with supplements, such as: 1. More stable source: you are sure that most of the vitamin is active (also the so called protiens products and even the natural protein sources are not stable orally!). 2.Fibre: good for bowl and Wight control. 3. Modest amount: less side effects (applies to amino acids* intake as well). 4. Gastrointestinal relief (usually high alkalinity and less concentration). 5. Won't increase your appetite too much (bcz of the concentration difference again).

Some people will argue sugar intake will increase.. OK this will be bad when you only drink the fruits, where usually no fibre there and lots of sugar bcz of many pieces of fruits needed for a one cup

*notice I said amino acids bcz I don't quite understand why people say proteins (unless if they were injectables). Proteins are very sensitive collection of amino acids, and have two big issues if taken orally, they will be degraded by stomach acidity and they won't be absorbed systematically because they are very big (the latter issue could be related to vitamin B12 with some people). As far as I know oral proteins are still in research, I heard researchers will be able to launch oral insulin soon thanks to the smart formulation.. but we will see

I gave the documentary a watch and thought it was really good. Much of the cinematics look masterfully shot, and the voice over is far better than the usual style you get in a documentary. However i hated the childish songs, fairly frustrating to watch. Im sure they took allot of time to make however in future projects i think it could be better spent elsewhere. Perhaps you could find a different more effective way to break up the video and achieve a similar effect in future projects. That said, it was the only part i didnt like about the documentary, which is a great accomplishment given how nit picky it is. Overall really good work.

Also, although the streaming quality was good, i did not like the service you used to publish the documentary and would definitely prefer to see it on more traditional services such as the google play store and itunes store. That said they did take paypal and didnt require me to make an account so i was happy about that. And the price to both buy and rent were more than fair and well with it. I look forward to enjoying more content like this in the future.

In an ideal world, we would get all of our vitamins, minerals and other nutrients the old fashion way, through hunting, raising livestock and homesteading. However, we don't live in an ideal world; we live in a fast paced world of instant gratification with poor diets and then try to rely on supplements instead of targeting our nutritional needs at the source. While not for everyone, more and more people are picking up homesteading once again to sustain healthier lives. Those that do can supplement what they don't hunt, raise or grow through trade/barter. Those that don't homestead or hunt can still trade/barter with other means.

Derek, I have loved and enjoyed Veritasium since your slingshot gravity and black swan videos back in the day. I genuinely enjoy your videos, however, I have a small gripe regarding your advertisement of Vitamania. You advertise yourself as a doctor on your website link, which, I know to be technically true due to your ph.d. When people link to your website they may see you as an authority on medicinal studies, even though your ph.d is in physics education research. I am not trying to say a ph.d in that is not relevant to the movie you make. The point I am trying to make is that when a layperson sees Dr. In front of a name on a video about health topics they regard that person as an authority on the matter (e.g Dr. Oz). Although you at least ARE in fact a Doctor, whereas Oz is not. I am concerned your advertisement branch went a little overboard in trying to sell this movie, and you may be unintentionally marketing yourself as a Ph.d in medicine to those who do not know better.

TL;DR
Vitamins A, D, E, K are soluble in fat, you can overdose on them. Suplements of the fat-soluble vitamins require proper dosing. Vitamins C, B are soluble in water, you will simply pee any surplus. Taking vitamin C and B suplements is harmless, high doses are just a waste.
In the developed world, it is extremely easy and cheap to eat a balanced diet containing all vitamins is sufficient doses.

Take vitamins and worsen or stagnante

So, basically, know what you're taking and how much you need.
